questions.text: A patient was presented with the exacerbated chronic lower back pain in the sacral region with irradiation to the back of the left leg, producing a strong pain throbbing and burning behind the knee. Pain was aggravated when bending forward or in reaching out position. In his history, he had a back condition from birth and later had an accident that resulted in fracture of the lumbar vertebrae. His MRI two months prior to this aggravation, showed degeneration of L1, disc degeneration, and protrusion of the disc at the S1 level. He was prescribed strong non-steroid pain medication that made him feel drowsy, but did not provide a full pain relief. Seeking resolution for his pain, he decided to try InterX therapy and treatment was aimed at whole Lumbosacral zone, dermatomes L1/L2 and L4, L5, S1-S3, left buttock, right buttock, left back of the knee. After two and a half weeks use, he reported no pain, no discomfort, he stopped taking pain medication and started with the core exercise program to stabilize the lumbar spine. Advice to limit driving, prolong sitting, rest, good nutrition, and gentle stretching exercises. Six months follow up confirmed that the patient still did not have pain, actively working and travelling. All of the following anatomical statements are true about this case except:

questions.text: During your rural posting after the internship, you encounter a patient of acute cardiac failure. Your preferred drug for this condition is dobutamine. However, it is not available there. Which of the following other drugs, or combination of drugs, would be a suitable alternative, giving the pharmacologic equivalent of what you want the dobutamine to do?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Norepinephrine plus phentolamine

questions.text: At an epidemiology conference in Toronto, Dr. Arjun Singh, an esteemed epidemiologist, showcased a compelling longitudinal study. In his study, 45,000 men were diligently monitored over 25 years, of which 2,500 developed prostate cancer. In an attempt to enhance the depth of the study, an additional 3,500 men confirmed to be healthy were included as controls. Dr. Singh highlighted that at the start of the study, potential risk factors were deduced from baseline data gathered through questionnaires disseminated to both sets of participants along with their blood samples which were stored after proper labelling. This strategic approach was designed to trace the onset of disease over an extended period, subsequently analysing it with the baseline data. Which terminology best describes this study design?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Nested case-control study

questions.text: A 26-year-old G3P3 is postpartum day 1 following an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. She reports sharp, intermittent lower abdominal pain, which is more severe than in her prior deliveries. Her heart rate is 84 beats per minute, blood pressure 110/60 mmHg, and her temperature 99.3°F. Her abdomen is soft on examination and there is no uterine tenderness. A scant amount of lochia is appreciated on a speculum examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Afterpains

questions.text: Dr. Ayesha Gupta, an emergency medicine specialist, is conducting a training session for first responders on mass casualty incidents. She emphasizes the importance of a specific triage system that rapidly assesses victims based on their ability to walk, respiratory status, perfusion, and mental function. This system prioritizes patients based on the severity of their injuries to ensure that those who are most likely to survive with immediate treatment are attended to first, which is known as START Triage. What is the correct full form of START?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Simple Triage and Rapid Treatment
